column4: I have to remove a package and then reinstall a newer version with .debs. How can I remove the package without removing it's dependencies?
or at least, without having to reconfigure them if I have to reinstall them?
did you try just installing it?
for some reason the whole thing needs to be done in a very specific order... here's what I'm doing http://blog.siansiew.com/2011/08/30/installing-mysql-5-5-on-ubuntu-11-04-natty/
did you try just doing the command he posted?
it'll remove php5-mysql, sphinxsearch, phpmyadmin, and some other things which I need
you can more easily track package dependecies in aptitude
I know, I'm just not sure how I can prevent it from uninstalling certain things as part of the resolution
so you want to remove packages withou installing them back anymore, and expect other packages which depend on the first, to work? I doubt it will work, a package will need a depency to work.
you can hold packages in aptitude
I'm going to remove mysql with aptitude, then install it with dpkg
so just remember those which got removed and you still want. :) install them again afterwards
won't their data be removed as well? or no?
nothing user configurable, though I don't know mysql installation.
dpkg should be able to list all files of a package, but user config shouldn't be a problem, just backup it for good measure.
